millsfield:images_texts:
The
Alia
Saga
Imprinted outside, on the fuselage of the aircraft.
is the emblazoned crown of the Hashemites and
the Jordanian flag. These are the symbols of the
two forces that created a national airline for Jor-
dan: Alia literally meaning "High; Alia is also the
name of King Hussein's eldest daughter.
In December 1963 following the royal decree that
a national airline should be established, Alia
The Royal Jordanian Airline came into being. it
was founded by Mr. Ali Ghandour, a young Jor-
danian engineer and now present chairman of
the airline. Beirut was the first Alia international
destination. Cairo, Kuwait, and Jeddah were
later added to the itinerary.
Alla
Ever since Alia has become a source of pride and
profit for Jordan. But between then and now
there had been traumatic stages in starting the
airline. There were no aircraft, employees
offices, pilots, ground crew or sales agents in
Jordan or out-side. Yet in a week's time the first
Alia aircraft took to wings, foreign pilots had
been hired, offices rented, technical workshops
set up and a private capital of JD 164,000 was
raised to buy a DC-7.
There were only three co-pilots in Jordan when
Alia began to operate. Two of them flying DC-3s,
and the third a Viscount, but now Alia is run by
professionals. Heading the organization is the
chairman who is also chief executive officer and
president, ten vice-presidents. each V.P. is the
president of his own department.
Simultaneously an Aero Club was formed to give
the people an incentive to study aviation and to
convince them of the safety of flying airplanes.
Since then the Aero Club has become another
branch of Alia. With 30 airplanes, the academy
trains students straight from high school, about
the theoretical and practical aspects of civil
aviation. Once the training at the academy is
